message_1:
Let X be the space obtained by identifying the points on the circumference of a unit square in the following way: Identify each point of the top side of the square with the point diametrically opposite it on the bottom side, and identify each point of the left side with the point diametrically opposite it on the right side. 

Calculate the fundamental group of X at any point.
message_2:
To compute the fundamental group of X, we can use the Seifert-van Kampen theorem. First, we will divide the square into two open sets U and V such that U covers the top and bottom sides of the square and V covers the left and right sides of the square. The intersection of U and V will be a cross shape in the middle of the square.

Now, let's consider the identifications. The top and bottom sides of the square are identified, so U is homeomorphic to a cylinder. Similarly, the left and right sides of the square are identified, so V is also homeomorphic to a cylinder. The intersection of U and V is homeomorphic to a cross shape, which deformation retracts onto a wedge of two circles.

Using the Seifert-van Kampen theorem, we have:

π1(X) = (π1(U) * π1(V)) / π1(U ∩ V)

Since U and V are both homeomorphic to cylinders, their fundamental groups are isomorphic to the integers Z:

π1(U) = π1(V) = Z

The intersection U ∩ V is homeomorphic to a wedge of two circles, so its fundamental group is the free product of two copies of Z:

π1(U ∩ V) = Z * Z

Now, we can compute the fundamental group of X:

π1(X) = (Z * Z) / Z

The fundamental group of X is the free product of two copies of Z, which is isomorphic to the free group on two generators:

π1(X) = F_2

So, the fundamental group of X at any point is the free group on two generators.
